instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S0SW_LCD: What is PP3V3_S0SW_LCD? PP3V3_S0SW_LCD is a 3.3v power rail necessary to power the image circuitry on the screen. This is necessary to get a picture on the screen. .
definitions.EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN: What is EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN? EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN is necessary to enable the power rail that powers the LCD screen image circuitry. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message:
Clean board no water damage and no more history, I have image on external screen.

<SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PANEL_P5V_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PANEL_P3V3_EN</SIGNAL> come on for about 1 second then leave
All tests are done with good LCD connected and new LCD flex.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message: Yes  <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> pulses same as the other ones mentioned before.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message: Did you test with another LCD assembly?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message: Yes, pulses once same as the other ones mentioned before.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message:
Seems to be a problem with CPU eDP video output.
It should detect LCD presence and maintain the voltages, once <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> goes high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message: Can check diode mode to ground on <SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_N</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_P</SIGNAL> to see if the transceiver inside the CPU is completely dead at least.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message: Thanks [USER=1057]@piernov[/USER]  <SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_N</SIGNAL>  is OL and  <SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_P</SIGNAL> is 0.211 measured in diode mode, I dont have another board to compare, any input will be greatly appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message:
You must get almost same value on both lines; red probe connected to ground.
The CPU eDP output is damaged...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image
threads.message:
Thanks, that is what I figured, yes red probe on gnd.

Thanks again for all the help.
